PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The La Porte SMR resolves all findings of its PHA and other hazard reviews some of which result in modifications of the process.  Most recently La Porte SMR executed the following safety improvement projects:
•	Modified boiler sight glass so that it is accessible and can be isolated while standing on the platform. It previously needed to be accessed from a ladder. (2022)
•	Upgraded 18x20 Syngas piping tee to a new metallurgy to prevent future leaks.  (2022)
•	Coated all ladder rungs in the plant with slip resistant coating.  (2022)
•	Changed all rusted bolts on the natural gas piping flanges.  (2019)
•	Added a platform to access the steam turbine inlet vent so it no longer needs to be accessed by ladder.  (2021)
•	Upgraded expansion joint material on combustion air fan to prevent future leaks.  (2022)
•	Upgraded boiler blowdown stand pipe to a proper blowdown drum to avoid potential hot water exposure to employees.  (2022)
•	Upgraded all steam traps in the plant to a better model less susceptible to failure and made each one isolatable while operating so that if one does fail it can be changed out online. This prevents continuous steam venting throughout the facility.  (2019)
•	Upgraded the process gas boiler bypass valve. The valve would stick causing operations to have to force it with a wrench (safety hazard) when they needed to move it. Upgraded the design and packing and the valve has not gotten stuck in 4 years.  (2019)
•	Upgraded the insulation on the hot combustion air preheater. This exchange had a history of cracking and releasing hot combustion air creating a safety hazard for employees.  It has not leaked in 4 years since the upgrade.  (2019)

Compliance Audits
To help ensure the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Air Liquide conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accidental release prevention program are being implemented.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years.  Resolutions to the recommendations are documented, tracked and closed.
 
Incident Investigation
Air Liquide defines management systems and establishes the requirements for communicating, investigating and reporting of incidents at all facilities through the use of an Incident Investigation and reporting procedure.  Air Liquide documents incident and subsequent investigation, follow up actions, and closure.  Results of findings and corrective actions are shared with employees who could be affected by the findings. 
 
 Employee Participation
At the La Porte SMR, employees are expected to participate in accidental release prevention program (PSM/RMP).   Employees are trained on and are provided access to the hydrogen process safety information.  The specific ways an employee can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in the Employee Participation plan.  Forms of participation include being part of a PHA, MOC, a PSSR, and/or being involved in incident investigation. participating in the review of the covered process operating procedures annually to ensure they are correct and recommend any necessary changes.

Management of Change
Air Liquide's management of change (MOC) procedure has established the requirements for ensuring that proposed process or equipment changes or changes indirectly affecting processes are evaluated, approved, and documented prior to implementation through the use of a management of change process.  The MOC procedure outlines the requirements for documenting, evaluating the impact, and approving planned changes  All MOC's are submitted, reviewed by subjective matter specialist (such as Engineering, Risk Management, Operations, Health and Safety), approved, tracked, and closed.  Personnel whose assigned job functions are impacted by the MOC, are briefed and /or trained in the MOC requirements.
 
Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)
Air Liquide ensures the safety of new/modified facilities or processes before placing those facilities or processes into service through the use of pre-startup safety reviews (PSSRs).  PSSRs are intended to ensure safety through confirmation that:  (1) construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications; (2) safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and adequate; (3) PHAs have been performed and recommend

key information for operating the process safely. 
 
Process Hazard Analysis
Air Liquide has a risk management program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  The covered process underwent an initial process hazard analysis (PHA) in September 2009 and routinely undergoes periodic review/re-validations at least every five years.  The PHA team consists of members with the appropriate experience to define the hazards.   The PHA team will reviews findings and develops a resolution action plan for each item, which is documented, tracked and ultimately closed in the Air Liquide action item tracking system. 
 
Operating Procedures
Air Liquide maintains written procedures that address various modes of hydrogen purification process operations, such as (1) unit initial startup; (2) unit normal and temporary operations; (3) unit shutdown; (4) emergency shutdown; (5) startup following an emergency shutdown; and (6) process deviation, consequence and action.  These procedures are used by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures are reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.
 
Training
Air Liquide has implemented a training program for all employees involved in operating the hydrogen purification process.  All employees receive a combination of classroom, computer-based (CBT) and hands-on training that addresses such topic as:  general orientation, site rules and practices, process safety information, normal and emergency operating procedures, health and safety consideration, use of safety procedures and equipment, incident investigation and emergency response.  In addition, all operators are required to attend refresher training at least every three years.  Training is documented and tracked in the electronic learning management system as well as well as in the local employee files.

OVERVIEW
Air Liquide Large Industries, L.P. (Air Liquide) operates a steam methane reforming (SMR) process in in La Porte, Texas (the SMR is considered the covered process, as defined in the accidental release prevention regulations, having a flammable mixture in the process in excess of 10,000 pounds).  The SMR process involves reforming natural gas feedstock into hydrogen.  The hydrogen purification process is closely monitored and controlled to prevent accidental releases to the environment. 
 
Regulated Chemical
The SMR process is designed to provide an efficient production of high purity hydrogen product using natural gas feedstock.  Purified hydrogen is sold to Industrial customer(s).  The La Porte Hydrogen Plant also produces steam and electricity, sold directly to nearby industrial customers.  The La Porte SMR is designed for continuous operation and is designed for inherently safe operation.
 
GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS
Air Liquide's La Porte SMR is covered by EPA's accidental release prevention program regulations and is subject to OSHA's process safety management (PSM) standard.  The flammability of some of the chemicals in the process makes it necessary for Air Liquide to observe certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human and environmental exposure and to reduce the potential threat to personnel and nearby members of the community.  Air Liquide's policy is to comply with all applicable federal and state rules and regulations. The summary below discusses some of the management system in place to implement the accidental release prevention program.
 
Process Safety Information (PSI)
Air Liquide keeps a variety of technical documents onsite and electronically that are used to help maintain safe operation of its processes.
